chapter.title: GNOME Accessibility - Pre-Distribution OS Testing for Accessibility Tools
chapter.para: This chapter is for OS distribution testers and outlines how to verify the functionality of GNOME accessibility tools prior to releasing new OS distributions.

Thank you for taking the time and care to better understand what you need to do to help ensure accessibility works on your distribution. This chapter provides methods to quickly verify that GNOME accessibility is functioning properly on your operating system distribution.

section.title: Test Xserver
section.para: Xserver is required for all distributions; for Linux and OpenSolaris, it should be Xorg. You can find them in both /etc/X11 and /usr/bin. Generally for Linux there will be a symbol link in /etc/X11/X and it is always linked to the binary Xorg in /usr/bin/Xorg. For OpenSolaris, you can find this process with the command ps -ef | grep X.

section.title: Test Speech
section.para: Orca uses GNOME Speech for speech synthesis.

step.para: Run the test-speech application by opening a terminal window (AltF1 and then Applications - Accessories - Terminal) and typing test-speech Enter.

A list of speech synthesis engines should be displayed. These may include eSpeak, Festival and others. Enter the number corresponding to the speech synthesizer engines you need to test. Ideally, no errors will be encountered. If you have no servers listed or errors are being listed, confirm you have included all the required packages for your OS build.
Use the various tests listed by the speech engine to confirm speech and audio output.

Verify that speech works in conjunction with other audio output applications like Movie Player or Rhythmbox Music Player. If the two audio sources can't be heard simultaneously, consider the following:

listitem.para: Shipping a speech synthesis engine with your operating system, such as eSpeak
Including gnome-speech and the GNOME Speech driver for the speech synthesis engine(s) you choose to ship
Exploring how to make audio work better on your distribution, especially audio mixing

section.title: Test Braille
section.para: Orca uses BrlTTY and liblouis for braille output.

step.para: Verify BrlTTY by opening a new terminal window and typing brltty -d /dev/term/0 -bxw -xno -p none -A auth=none -n. A little BrlTTY window should appear. If the BrlTTY window doesn't appear, or any errors are shown, then you have some work to do.
Ensure the Python bindings for BrlTTY are installed by typing python -c "import brlapi" - if it produces errors, you probably don't have the Python bindings installed.
Ensure liblouis is installed by typing [ TBD ] in a terminal window.
Test if BrlTTY automatically starts when a USB braille device is plugged in.

section.title: Test Magnification
section.para: Orca uses GNOME Mag for magnification. For a compelling magnification experience, GNOME Mag uses various X Windows System server extensions: COMPOSITE, FIXES, DAMAGE, RANDR, and RENDER.

step.para: Verify GNOME Mag works by opening a terminal window and typing magnifier -h. The magnifier should come up in split-screen mode.

Run Orca and open the Magnifier preferences tab in the Preferences GUI. Enable magnification by selecting the checkbox at the top of the magnifier preferences tab. The magnifier should come up in full-screen mode by default. If it doesn't, you might not have the appropriate X Windows System server extensions installed/enabled, or you might be running into some odd conflict with a compositing manager, such as Compiz. If you're using Compiz, try going back to Metacity and starting over.

section.title: Test AT-SPI
section.para: Orca uses the AT-SPI to communicate with applications on the desktop.

step.para: Enable assistive technologies for your login session. You should be able to do this by checking the "Enable assistive technologies" checkbox in the "Assistive Technologies" preferences dialog and then logging out and back in again. If you're bold and really want to do the right thing, you can ship with accessibility enabled by default for your distribution. This can be done by modifying the default gconf values:

Login with accessibility enabled. You should not get any errors. Check xprop -root | grep AT_SPI_IOR. If you don't see an AT_SPI_IOR property on your root window, then something is wrong with your infrastructure. The usual cause of this is not setting the --libexecdir properly when building AT-SPI. Search the Orca WIKI Download/Install page for libexecdir for more information.

section.title: Test Accessibility-Related Themes
section.para: The GNOME Desktop provides some themes which have been designed with low vision and other disabilities in mind.

step.para: Press AltF1 and select System - Preferences - Appearance. The Appearance preference tool is displayed with multiple tabs along the top.
Select the Theme tab and verify the accessibility themes are installed; these include High Contrast, High Contrast Inverse, High Contrast Large Print Inverse, etc.

Select the various themes and verify they are working; apply any suggested fonts as you test the themes. Confirm that applications to be used comply with accessibility; eg, any custom visible widgets should be compliant with the selected theme and auto-adjust for color, widget size, and font size.

section.title: Test Keyboard Accessibility (AccessX)
section.para: AccessX delivers extended keyboard features for users with physical impairments. Toggle keys, sticky keys, bounce keys, mouse keys and other features are included with customization of each feature available through a single interface.

StickyKeys - provides locking or latching of modifier keys (eg, Shift, Ctrl) so that they can be used without simultaneously pressing the keys being modified. This allows single finger operation of multiple key combinations.
MouseKeys - an alternative to the mouse which provides keyboard-based explicit control of cursor movement and all mouse button press/release events.
RepeatKeys - delays the onset of key repeat, allowing users with limited coordination time to release keys before multiple characters are sent.
SlowKeys - requires a key to be held down for a set period before the key is accepted. This allows users with limited coordination to accidentally press keys without sending inadvertant key events.
ToggleKeys - indicates locking key state with a tone when pressed; eg, Caps Lock.
BounceKeys - requires a delay between keystrokes before accepting the next key press so users with tremors can prevent the system from accepting inadvertent key presses.

step.para: Press AltF1 and select System - Preferences - Keyboard. The Keyboard preference tool is displayed with multiple tabs along the top.
Select the Accessibility tab and enable Sticky Keys, Slow Keys and Bounce Keys.
Verify the functionality of the features just enabled by interacting with the operating system and various applications.

section.title: Test Accessible Login
section.para: The GNOME Desktop provides a login procedure which supports accessibility tools. If not properly functioning, many disabled users will not even make it to the desktop.

note.para: Accessible login features are presently 100% functioning for Solaris only.

section.para: Run at-spi-registryd within a terminal to judge whether assistive technology support has been enabled. You may want to additionally perform these steps:

step.para: Search for "Greeter" and replace Greeter=/usr/lib/gdmgreeter to Greeter=/usr/lib/gdmlogin
Arrow down to the line #AddGtkModules=false and change "false" to "true"; also, un-comment this line by removing the pound symbol (#) from the start of the line.
Arrow down to the line #GtkModulesList=gail:atk-bridge:/usr/lib/gtk-2.0/modules/libdwellmouselistener:/usr/lib/gtk-2.0/modules/libkeymouselistener and un-comment it.
Search for Definition and add the two parameters +kb +accessx at the end of the command=... line if these two parameters are absent.
Save your changes and close the file.
Bring gdm online with the following commands: /usr/dt/bin/dtconfig -d and svcadm enable svc:application/graphical-login/gdm:default
Add user "gdm": open and edit the file /etc/passwd, search for gdm, change this line to gdm:x:50:50:GDM Reserved UID:/etc/X11/gdm/home:, then save your changes and close the file.
Go to the directory /etc/X11/gdm and enter the commands mkdir home and chown gdm:gdm home
Reboot the machine. All the mouse/key gestures are recorded in the /etc/X11/gdm/modules directory.

section.title: Enabling XKB on Solaris
section.para: The XKB extension is a required component for supporting additional input devices.

step.para: Check if the path and file /etc/dt/config/Xservers exists on your systems; if not, enter the commands: mkdir -p /etc/dt/config and cp /usr/dt/config/Xservers /etc/dt/config/Xservers
Open the Xservers file in a text editor and scroll to the end of the file and append the following to the command line at the end of the file: +kb
Enter the following command: pkill -HUP dtlogin
Log out of your GNOME session and log in again.
To verify if XKB is running, enter xdpyinfo and search for XKEYBOARD in the extensions list.
